body: Please correct commit message (prefix and description) and add unit tests.
Thanks for the contribution! Please adhere to the commit guidelines (jira issue, commit message)

@msumit 

Remember to prefix your commit and PR with '[AIRFLOW-XXX]' as per https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributors%27+Guide

When we create release notes, we extract the commit title, so it's important to adhere to this convention and to require contributors to as well. 

Also, can you add some tests here?
Thanks for the contribution! Please extend the unit tests (they didn't catch the previous issue) and improve commit message (subject length, description).
LGTM
Commit message is still incorrect needs to be in [AIRFLOW-xxx] format.
Also please add a description to your commit message per guidelines. Thanks!
Thanks for the rephrase @r39132 ;-)
Sure, will update it.

@btallman Thanks for your contribution.

See my comments on #1731 and how the submitter corrected it on #1733

In addition to a call for references, we also want to acclimate potential future contributors with the apache commit guidelines. This is required before I can merge your change.

You commits and PRs need to be prefixed by `[AIRFLOW-XXX]` to make it easy to generate release notes. Please fix and ping me when ready
Also, please fix style errors per landscape

Fixed. Sorry, once you sent that, the format clicked...

Thanks,
Ben

## 

Ben Tallman - 503.680.5709

On Fri, Aug 19, 2016 at 2:23 PM, Sid Anand notifications@github.com wrote:

> @btallman https://github.com/btallman Thanks for your contribution.
> 
> See my comments on #1731
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1731 and how the
> submitter corrected it on #1733

> future contributors with the apache commit guidelines. This is required
> before I can merge your change.
> 
> You commits and PRs need to be prefixed by [AIRFLOW-XXX] to make it easy
> to generate release notes. Please fix and ping me when ready
> 
> ‚Äî
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub

> or mute the thread

> .
@bolkedebruin @criccomini @aoen @artwr @mistercrunch @jlowin ?
LGTM
(assuming travis passes reasonably)

No worries. You also need to modify your commit message, because that's what will be used in the release note ultimately, but I can fix it for now when I merge - one of the cool features of @jlowin merge tools is fixing issues like this, but we want contributors to still follow the convention in case the safety net fails. Please make sure to edit and push future commits with the correct format rules.
And welcome to the Apache Airflow community [officially]! Looking forward to your talk at the next meetup

@bolkedebruin are you replying to jbalogh's comment about their use of sigterm?

I agree that normal behavior is to shutdown on SIGTERM. One thing to note is that celery now responds SIGTERM by doing a warm shutdown, so airflow worker (currently) automatically inherits that behavior.

@waltherg I think the gunicorn syntax error is just a warning (https://github.com/benoitc/gunicorn/issues/788) and won't cause the build to fail (eg https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-airflow/jobs/153691508)
üëç
@criccomini @jlowin any concerns? Looks pretty good to me.
@r39132 go for it
@cerisier thanks!
üëç
Thx @ananya77041 For future reference, you should add the [AIRFLOW-XXX] prefix to your commit as well. Cheers and Welcome to the Apache Airflow community!
Will keep in mind. Thanks!
@bolkedebruin I think we both updated this page within a couple of minutes ;-) Are you checking airflow from a beach or something similarly wonderful?

@jgao54 kindly rebase and ping me when ready for a review. This sort of change is what we need to make airflow play better with provisioning automation (e.g. ansible, salt, chef, puppet), so thank you. What we also need a file-based option for the CLI. If not in this PR, please consider implementing it in a subsequent PR. For example, check out what https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1691 did for variables. There was also a UI enhancement to support file import and export in https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1696
Just got back. Still a Jet lag to recover from!
Copacabana is great though!

@bolkedebruin @r39132 did the changes as suggested. There is some issue with landscape, it shows arbitrary errors after rebase.

Please, follow 50/72 rule for commit messages. Also PR title should be of [AIRFLOW-XXX] format. Please see contribution guidelines at https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributors%27+Guide
changes lgtm.
Please include unit tests.
changes lgtm.. but plz update the commit message (add [AIRFLOW-XXX]) and follow 50/72 rule. See commit guidelines here https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributors%27+Guide
lgtm
Nice. Can you update your commit with a description and proper title?
@zodiac yes. I probably misread jbalogh's comment. SIGHUP should reread config and continue operations ( or rolling restart if required). SIGTERM should do a warm shutdown.
Why just not add some tests with mock? It will help verify py2 compat.
Travis builds fails consistently. Can you check whether you are up to date?
@zodiac Can you verify if this works for you guys?

@vineet-rh gave a bit more thought. I like it! Storing everything in UTC seems logical. I understand that testing is a bit hard. A test could be setting a date in a different timezone for a particular dag en verify this date gets into UTC in the db and other parts?
@bolkedebruin will try it this tuesday

@bolkedebruin Yep, just recently got wiki access. Let me get to that on Monday. 

@r39132 Since there are multiple processes, and each process schedules one file, scheduling should be distributed and fast. It's strange that the SequentialExecutor is slow. During testing, I used the SequentialExecutor and did not run into any issues. I'll try it again this week.

Unfortunately, I have a bit of a backlog as I am taking care of tasks before heading offline from 8/26 - 9/3. I'm not entirely sure I'll be able to get to the `SequentialExecutor` testing in the next couple of days, but I'll update here if I can.

Thx @mistercrunch.

Please note guidelines in https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/Contributors%27+Guide 
1. Create a JIRA
2. Preface your commit message and PR with [AIRFLOW-XXX]
3. Place a link to your JIRA in this body of the PR
No. That should be removed.
The existing commit (f1f1cad) looks good -- is the index going to be part of this PR?

@bolkedebruin So I pulled the latest code from master and tried it out with a test DAG using the LocalExecutor, and it seems to be running without unexpected delays for me. I'm wondering if the issue you're seeing is related to the minimum DAG file processing interval that was introduced in this PR. The default value is 3 minutes, which in retrospect, seems long.

I put out a PR (https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1761) to change the default so that it runs as fast as possible.

Thanks for the documentation and for the change. Just waiting for travis and landscape to pass. Can you run these in your fork and send me a link if they pass. And will +1 once they do either in your fork or here.
@plypaul it might be, however I am observing it in between scheduler loops as well and I hope that that is not affected by this setting. I'll test it asap
I'll test it hopefully today

üëç The commit message should be in active voice such as "Add default failure handler for qubole operator" and should be within the 50 characters for the commit subject. It's unclear if the 50 character limit includes the `[AIRFLOW-XXX]` prefix, but generally try to stay in that limit. I'll modify your commit message when I merge, but please be aware of it in the future.
Also, just noticed you didn't leave a line between the subject and body. These are the 7 rules we follow: http://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/#seven-rules

Ok i have just tested it. It has improved, but I also see that the delay in processing is applied between scheduling of the task instances. This means that a first instance is launched and then the scheduler will wait ~3min before scheduling the next task (with the old config values). I don't think that is the idea behind these config items. At least I think that tasks from a running dag should be scheduled as soon as they are available for running, no extra delay should be added on behalf of the scheduler.

What is the reasoning behind this configuration and delay by the way?

In addition I observe that Pools are often "under used" (only 6 slots used but 8 available, task instances are queued) and also slots_used are not recorded in the UI view.

The idea behind the delay was that there wasn't a need to process DAGs so quickly - with higher thread counts you could be processing a given DAG every few seconds. To reduce the log volume and potential load on the DB, the configurable delay was added.

For the case that you're seeing - could you enable debug logging and send me the log contents?

Ok will do when I have to chance. I also noticed that the scheduler now quits by default after X time. I think this should _not_ be the default and in addition documentation and upgrade notes should be updated on this (I didn't check, but assume it wasn't). I was really caught by surprise with this.
üéÜ

What if you have to remove the DAG file out yourself before running the CLI command?
It could have another option: "show list of obsolete DAGs".

We keep a separate directory of obsolete jobs just to archive them. I have no problem saying 
"git mv dags/job.py archived/job.py"
before running the database purger.

Hey @jlowin , this seems like a good addition and indeed breaking. But I think that 1.8 branch does contain a few other breaking changes as well. While I'm building up infrastructure at work I'm adding documentation. Maybe we could document the breaking changes that will be in 1.8. I'll start a long running Pull Request on this so you can follow. I'm sure @criccomini also will comment on this PR.
üëç

Hi! I understand this problem this fix is meant to address. What you are suggesting is in fact the way things worked a few weeks ago.. if merged, we will be back to an issue that occurs when a "clear" operation is called - which results in a lot of dag runs being scheduled at one time and not honoring max_dag_runs. I need to spend some time looking at this today so that we can support both. The issue seems to be the way dags are currently prioritized... in a cross-dag run order over a in-dag run order.
`Checking` -> `Check` in commit message (http://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/#imperative)
